So maybe people spend less time on Twitter, or my tweets are seen less, or my tweets suck üòÇ
Anyways, something has definitely been changing in general and I‚Äôm not the only one to notice.

Maybe that‚Äôs due to some accounts having previously bought followers, I can‚Äôt say, but speaking for myself I never have bought followers and I definitely have seen a reduction in view counts on my tweets even though my follower count has more than doubled over the past 2 years.

Generally speaking and just based on observation general tweets see view-counts of about 5%-20% of an account‚Äôs follower count.
Heck I‚Äôve seen accounts with multiple millions of followers that barely see 50k-70k views on their Tweets.

Since the view counts have been made public what I had suspected for a while is that the vast majority of Twitter accounts are either inactive or don‚Äôt see tweets or a combination of both.
While nobody should expect a 100% view count, viral tweets aside, view counts are very low.

Some observations:
1. Before Elon took over I already noticed a down trend in engagement across the board for many accounts following Covid peak. This may be due to general social media fatigue, also more employed.
2. Recent algorithm changes have impacted visibility further.

What remains impressive to me is how controlled the 2022 bear market has been. No major volatility spikes compared to history, no major corporate institutional blow ups yet, but they don‚Äôt happen until they do.
This leaves a runway for coming rallies & selling opportunities.

Bottomline: Politically they can‚Äôt afford another blow up for they will take the full blame. I suspect they know that.
So no matter what they say now take it with a huge grain of salt.
The data will change their tune fast.
And the math will demand it.

The Fed was supposed to be the lender of last resort in a crisis, but years of repeated and unaccountable policy mistakes have made the Fed the prime driver of creating the conditions for instability.
They have been the drivers of the excesses and like in 2008, when they forecasted no recession just as things were blowing up, they now risk setting themselves up in the same way.

If the Fed blows this & will have again misjudged the severity of the fall out it may not politically survive this as an institution in its current form.
Let‚Äôs not forget: They are now slamming the foot on the break after their colossal policy error in 2021.

Hence watch the data very closely over the next few months as the lag effects will filter through.
Corporations will do what they always do: preserve margins as best as possible & that means broad based layoffs.
The Fed will find itself faced with a very different economy quickly

We try to mix macro with technicals as best possible. Sometimes that is very challenging, but it's the technicals that had informed our bullish view in recent weeks hence I kept highlighting the positive technical backdrop despite all the horrid news.
It's a constant journey.

Think of all the negative macro chatter that was offered in Sept/Oct below the June lows.
Did that make you money staying on the short side?
Or did it that make you miss a major buying opportunity?
This is why technicals & flexibility in spite of a macro view are so important. https://t.co/z0SorSb77D

If you can't separate a macro view from a technical trade view at key market turning points you will eventually get run over.
Nothing moves in a straight line.

And perhaps that is what the market is sniffing out. Hence earnings bombs didn‚Äôt matter this week nor higher yields in October versus June.
Of course this could all be just seasonal,  technical and positioning related but best to keep an open mind as to the pulse of the market.

The lurking truth beneath may just be that despite all Volcker references this is a very different financial economy where what could be done back then can‚Äôt now & given deflationary technology & demographic trends doesn‚Äôt need to as specific crisis elements unwind already.

Why do you think Yellen‚Äôs US Treasury is working on a plan to buy bonds?
Why do you think Powell is getting letters from US politicians whining about rate hikes already?
Why do you think several Fed governors are already worried about over-tightening?

So what is this? A PR exercise to sound tough? All bark no bite?
Heck we‚Äôre already have seen the ghosts of financial stability concerns creeping about with the Fed funds rate at 3.08% and yields at 2008 highs.
Why? Because the debt construct can‚Äôt handle it.

To be clear: Volcker never waited to cut rates until inflation was vanquished back to 2%. Not even close so the reference seems to be off a bit.
And this much more indebted economy can‚Äôt handle rates above CPI as Volcker did initially so it‚Äôs not even possible for Powell to do.

These continued Volcker references leave me a bit baffled.
1. Volcker actually started cutting rates aggressively while CPI was still north of 10%. Why? Because the economy went into recession.
2. Debt to GDP was 30% vs 125% now.

Both factors need to be recognized.

The yield curve inversions give a 12-18 month window before a full recession hits and this leaves room for market rallies, especially in context of year end seasonality, mark ups, buybacks etc.

There is no example where the unemployment rate peaked at 4.4% coming from 3.5%. None. Rather the peaks following such low readings ends in at least 6%-8% or worse. So the Fed is clinging to a soft landing no recession narrative despite all history.

The Fed is still projecting positive GDP growth for all years going forward while also projecting unemployment to peak at 4.4% off of the current low of 3.5%. Given yield curve inversions and all of history there is simply no precedence for such a scenario: https://t.co/QuVCJ2zVLT

So yields need to come down as the Fed is in an uncomfortable box for politically they are increasingly under the hot spot and will surely be blamed if this filters into big unemployment numbers over the next couple of years.

Risk remains a Fed now boxed into a narrative. The challenge is to not create an even bigger problem, that of financial instability, by trying to fix the current problem, inflation, as the velocity of yields given the debt construct is unsustainable without breaking things. https://t.co/BHRdCKbwsJ
